bioghist.p: Leon de Valinger (d. 2000) served as the State Archivist of Delaware from 1941 to 1972. His contributions to establishing and strengthening Delaware's public archives program were so significant that, in 1989, the General Assembly renamed the Hall of Records building in Dover in his honor. He was a founding member of the Society of American Archivists and the author of numerous books, articles, and pamphlets on Delaware history. He played a key role in the preservation of the John Dickinson Mansion Museum, Buena Vista, Woodburn, the Old State House, and other historic sites in Delaware.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the personal and professional papers of Leon de Valinger. Professional papers include: subject files on many topics such as book repair, public archives, archaeology, craftsmen, churches, and authors; Delaware-related news clippings; files of the Delaware League of Local Governments (1984-1988); records of de Valinger's membership in professional associations and his participation in meetings and conferences; records of the Manuscript Supply Company (1970s-1980s); records related to the restoration of Buena Vista and other historic houses; correspondence from his time as State Archivist (1950-1954, 1958-1959, and 1962-1963); photographs; printed materials; maps; and Delaware ephemera. The collection also includes de Valinger's personal correspondence, calendars, diaries, household bills and correspondence regarding financial matters, health records, school notes, a 1924 high school year book, and items from his desk.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
